text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: mid (4-7 years of experience)

"I work at a start-up that's preparing to raise a series B. According to the plan, within one year of a successful raise, we will go from about 80 employees to more than 200. This headcount is desperately needed, but that's a LOT of hiring in a short period of time, and I imagine my own role (and seniority level) will also change drastically as a result. For example, I currently project manage, strategize, AND execute copy for an entire strategic piece of the business, and I could really use a team. Any advice to help me start thinking about, planning, and preparing for something like this?"

One process I've come across that I really like for expansion goes something like this:

Start logging your daily tasks, if you don't know em already

Rate these tasks on at least two dimensions:
1. how much you enjoy em
2. how good you are at em
3. (optional) how important they actually are
We will assume that they're all pretty important (but sometimes it's worth checking!)

Add or multiply your scores together—the top ones are things you'll likely want to keep close to you, and the bottom ones are first in line for being filled with someone who'd hopefully rank them in the opposite way you would.

Of course, if you rocket to the top of a big team, then your mindset may need to shift entirely to People Management vs Task Management... you should also take a good long while to understand if People management is a high rank for you or not. If not, then that is also someone to hire for, who will likely be at a level near or even more senior to you, despite you having a longer tenure.

text: Hey friends - so I've got a question. I'm currently at a fintech startup leading content, but I recently accepted a new role leading content at a cybersecurity company, whose primary customer base is mid-market businesses. This role came to me through a personal connection (CMO) and although I initially said no, she managed to win me more. I'm getting BAD case of new job jitters and feel like I just made a huge mistake. My question for all you is - has anyone here made the switch from a more "formal" b2b tech org to SaaS? I'm mostly panicking because I don't want to typecast myself as a cybersecurity content marketer, as I really enjoy creating content for SaaS instead. Any advice/tips?

elements.text: Hey friends - so I've got a question. I'm currently at a fintech startup leading content, but I recently accepted a new role leading content at a cybersecurity company, whose primary customer base is mid-market businesses. This role came to me through a personal connection (CMO) and although I initially said no, she managed to win me more. I'm getting BAD case of new job jitters and feel like I just made a huge mistake. My question for all you is - has anyone here made the switch from a more "formal" b2b tech org to SaaS? I'm mostly panicking because I don't want to typecast myself as a cybersecurity content marketer, as I really enjoy creating content for SaaS instead. Any advice/tips?

text: I wouldn’t worry too much about typecasting yourself. Cybersecurity is a great space, lots of room for innovation, experimentation, and impact with content. I think it comes down to your results: how is your content serving the audience and the business? The results you get and the stories you tell around that are extremely transferable!

elements.text: I wouldn’t worry too much about typecasting yourself. Cybersecurity is a great space, lots of room for innovation, experimentation, and impact with content. I think it comes down to your results: how is your content serving the audience and the business? The results you get and the stories you tell around that are extremely transferable!

text: Many of our clients here at PathFactory are in cybersecurity and I see them move between industries all the time. A great resource for you to get on your feet might be the Cybersecurity Marketing Society - really great resources, event, content for marketers like you: <https://cybersecuritymarketingsociety.com>

attachments.title: Homepage - Cybersecurity Marketing Society
attachments.fallback: Cybersecurity Marketing Society: Homepage - Cybersecurity Marketing Society

elements.text: Many of our clients here at PathFactory are in cybersecurity and I see them move between industries all the time. A great resource for you to get on your feet might be the Cybersecurity Marketing Society - really great resources, event, content for marketers like you:

text: Also, lean on your vendors to put you in the spotlight to showcase your strategy and results! Ask them for help speaking at events and winning awards that aren’t specific to cybersecurity so you get visibility outside of that space as well.

elements.text: Also, lean on your vendors to put you in the spotlight to showcase your strategy and results! Ask them for help speaking at events and winning awards that aren’t specific to cybersecurity so you get visibility outside of that space as well.

text:
Lots of great advice from <@URAV154AV>, especially this bit: "The results you get and the stories you tell around that are extremely transferable!"

I'd extend that to say that the processes you build are also transferrable.

elements.text:
, especially this bit: "The results you get and the stories you tell around that are extremely transferable!"

I'd extend that to say that the processes you build are also transferrable.

text: Mhm, I’d put emphasis on the “leading content” aspect of both those roles vs the industry itself. With that abstraction, you could lead content anywhere! Including where you’d prefer, when the time comes.

elements.text: Mhm, I’d put emphasis on the “leading content” aspect of both those roles vs the industry itself. With that abstraction, you could lead content anywhere! Including where you’d prefer, when the time comes.

text: I agree, with <@URAV154AV> I moved from a B2B SaaS space to a more B2B2C set-up, and was overwhelmed at first but soon realized that it isn't very different. The more you'll explore the more you'll see the similarities. Good luck with the new role :slightly_smiling_face:
